description: DNS query to youtu.be marked as high entropy domain; entropy detector triggered due to domain structure indicating possible encoded C2 communication.
DNS forwarding to 8.8.8.8 for high entropy domain (youtu.be); commonly used CDN, but flagged due to entropy threshold — likely benign.
DNS query to youtu.be detected again with high entropy warning; destination is commonly used and likely legitimate.
Forwarded DNS request for youtu.be flagged by entropy detector, but target is a common CDN — low likelihood of malicious use.
DNS response for youtu.be IP received; low entropy in reply, and the domain is not obscure — anomaly is likely not malicious.
Similar DNS reply with resolved IP for youtu.be; flagged only due to training model's entropy threshold — benign use case.
Low frequency of DNS A record queries for mail subdomain (mail.price.fox.org); could indicate targeted DNS probe or misconfiguration.
IMAP login disconnect with no authentication attempts could be indicative of an automated brute-force scanner or probing login availability.
Repeated IMAP login disconnect from same source across multiple logs (syslog); indicates scripted or automated login reconnaissance.
Duplicate alert of same IMAP login disconnect appearing in mail.info log — repeated failed attempts across logs consistent with reconnaissance.
Repeated failure to resolve hostname for IP address 192.168.130.77 can be indicative of automated scanning or misconfigured reconnaissance tools.
Duplicate log entry suggesting automated recon attempts; consistent IP lookup failures are typical of scanning activity.
HTTP access denied to restricted path by server configuration; typically caused by probing for default paths or unauthorized access attempts.
Second access denial to protected web directory; strongly suggests parallel probing from a different internal IP.
Continuation of failed hostname resolution from the same IP; part of a scanning or probing sequence.
Unexpected TLS packet received during connection; common in SSL/TLS reconnaissance or tool misconfiguration.
Another duplicate unresolved hostname error from same IP, reinforcing presence of active scanning.
Access to non-existent path using Nmap scripting engine, with 403 response; typical of service or path enumeration.
POST request to /sdk endpoint using Nmap scripting engine; intended to test service exposure or gather info.
Basic HTTP GET request to root path from suspicious internal IP, resulting in 403; consistent with scanning attempts.
403 Forbidden response to a POST request from a user agent identified as the Nmap Scripting Engine suggests automated scanning for accessible endpoints.
Another POST request using the Nmap Scripting Engine user-agent being denied by server configuration confirms scanning activity across endpoints.
Access denied to the /HNAP1 path suggests probing for known vulnerable router or IoT endpoints, typical in reconnaissance.
Repeated access attempt to /HNAP1 path by same client IP indicates targeted probing of specific web application functionality.
Another instance of denied access to /HNAP1 from a different IP, indicating scanning activity targeting multiple systems.
Denied access to root web directory during same time frame as HNAP1 requests suggests broad reconnaissance.
Similar access denial to root directory from different client IP further supports coordinated scanning behavior.
403 response to a GET request for known WordPress plugin path by WPScan user-agent indicates enumeration of vulnerable plugins.
HEAD request to WordPress plugin path by WPScan tool indicates scanning for plugin enumeration.
Another HEAD request targeting different plugin path by WPScan tool shows breadth of scanning behavior for plugin discovery.
HEAD request to a known vulnerable WordPress plugin path using WPScan, indicating probing for plugin presence or vulnerabilities.
Use of HEAD request to test availability of another WordPress plugin path, a typical pattern in vulnerability enumeration with WPScan.
Probing for 'post-snippets' plugin using HEAD request, common during targeted scanning for plugin enumeration.
HEAD request to detect 'post-types-order' plugin presence, matching reconnaissance patterns seen in WordPress scans.
Testing for 'post-type-switcher' plugin with a HEAD request via WPScan, typical of scanning behavior.
HEAD request aimed at identifying presence of 'postmark-approved-wordpress-plugin' plugin, a fingerprinting step.
Attempt to detect 'postie' plugin via HEAD request using WPScan, fits reconnaissance activity.
HEAD request to known vulnerable 'timthumb.php' file in WordPress theme directory, indicative of exploit reconnaissance.
Repeated check to a slight path variant of 'timthumb.php', looking for file inclusion vulnerabilities, common in scans.
Malformed request with duplicate 'timthumb.php' indicates automated fuzzing/probing for vulnerable scripts.
Usage of 'HEAD' request on a known vulnerable file 'timthumb.php' by WPScan indicates reconnaissance targeting WordPress themes.
Another 'HEAD' request on a potential vulnerable script 'thumb.php' by WPScan shows continued enumeration for WordPress exploitation.
Attempted access to '.htpasswd', a sensitive file storing password hashes, blocked with HTTP 403. Indicates probing for credential files.
Access attempt to file '.htpasswd_' — a variation of sensitive file probing — again blocked with 403. Suggests fuzzing or enumeration.
Use of '@' in URL path indicates automated or fuzzing activity probing unconventional or malformed paths.
URL includes '~adm', likely targeting admin directories. Use of special characters suggests path brute-forcing.
Access attempt to 'info.php' in WordPress sitemaps path. File not found — typical probing behavior for known vulnerable endpoints.
Unusual request to 'lost+found' with '+' in path implies automated fuzzing or discovery of hidden directories.
Attempt to access 'phpinfo.php', commonly exploited to gain system configuration info if exposed.
Request to '~webmaster' inside a js directory indicates targeting of potentially hidden or deprecated admin files.
Request contains unusual character '~' in a WordPress path; often indicative of scanning or probing for known or misconfigured plugins or files.
Request for directory listing of a WordPress directory without proper DirectoryIndex; this is typical in automated reconnaissance for plugin enumeration.
Access attempt to `.hta` file in WordPress directory indicates an attempt to find hidden config or script files often used in exploits.
Access to a known WordPress plugin path resulting in a 301 redirect; common in automated path discovery or enumeration of components.
URL with uncommon character '+' in path suggests fuzzing or probing for edge cases or specific file naming conventions.
301 redirect when accessing plugin directory is a known indicator of path enumeration activity.
Request for `phpinfo.php`, a known PHP script used to leak environment information; typically used by attackers to assess server config.
301 redirect on accessing '/skins' plugin subdirectory; indicative of scanning behavior for WordPress plugin internals.
301 redirect from a request to '/themes' indicates probing for theme-based vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.
Attempted access to index.php within a WordPress theme directory, which is a common location for web shells or backdoors.
Unusual character '+' in URL path targeting WordPress theme file, likely probing for accessible or misconfigured files.
Request for non-existent PHP file in WordPress theme directory suggests probing for accessible or outdated resources.
Attempt to access 'phpinfo.php' is a common probe for vulnerable scripts to gather PHP environment info.
403 Forbidden access to potential internal script path hints at enumeration of resources or access restrictions testing.
Access attempt using uncommon '~' character in file paths implies scanning for hidden or backup files/directories.
Use of tilde-prefixed path (~lp) suggests scanning for user directories or symbolic links.
Attempt to access resource with tilde character targeting a possibly sensitive email-related resource ('~mail').
Access attempt to '~nobody' path may indicate search for user-based misconfigurations or exposed user directories.
Request for '~operator' suggests enumeration of user-specific directories or administrative backdoors.
Probing for 'info.php' file in WordPress subdirectory indicates search for sensitive diagnostic scripts.
Request to unusual path containing 'lost+found' directory name with new '+' character indicates possible probing for hidden or sensitive directories
Request for 'phpinfo.php' script which is often probed by attackers to gather detailed server info; script not found indicates reconnaissance
403 Forbidden status on request to social images directory suggests access control blocking possibly suspicious directory access

attack_type: Unauthorized Access Attempt / Web Shell Detection
description: 403 Forbidden on request for '.hta' file, often used for malicious scripts or web shells, suggests attacker probing for upload/execution
403 Forbidden on access to '.htpasswd' file, indicates attacker scanning for credential files to extract password hashes
403 Forbidden on '.htpasswd_' file, similar to '.htpasswd' probing, attacker attempts to find backup or alternate credential files
Request containing '@' character in path, unusual character in URL path, attacker may be testing URL parsing or special file paths
Request with '~adm' path indicating attempts to access user home directories or admin related paths, unusual character '~' detected
Request with '~admin' path, probing for user admin directories or shortcuts, presence of tilde character signals suspicious attempt
Apache error 'client denied by server configuration' on '.htaccess' file access shows server enforcing access restrictions, attacker probing protected files
Apache error log shows client denied access to .htaccess_ file in admin JS folder, likely probing for sensitive config files
Access denied to .htpasswd file indicates attacker probing for password files to gather credentials
Repeated attempt to access .htpasswd_ file, indicating persistence in probing for sensitive files
PHP script admin.php not found, attacker likely scanning for exploitable or admin scripts
PHP script index.php in admin folder missing, scanning for admin interface or vulnerable scripts
High entropy in URL with .php file and encoded parameters suggests web shell usage and code execution
Encoded parameters referencing github repo tags, likely for command retrieval or C2 communication
Encoded parameters with script execution and file operations indicate lateral movement or privilege escalation
Unusual POST request frequency on ajax.php endpoint indicates possible exploitation or API abuse
CPU usage spike deviates from baseline, could indicate resource exhaustion or DoS attack
Unusual high frequency of DNS queries from multiple IPs, possible use of DNS for command-and-control or data exfiltration
Unusual frequency of Apache request methods possibly indicating automated scanning or reconnaissance activity
High entropy HTTP GET request targeting PHP file with suspicious encoded parameters indicating web shell or command execution attempt
Successful 'su' command by www-data to user phopkins, indicating potential privilege escalation or lateral movement
Terminal session opened showing 'su' transition from www-data to phopkins, indicating interactive shell escalation
Session opened for user phopkins by www-data, confirming successful privilege escalation session
New authentication event for phopkins via /bin/su, possibly indicating credential harvesting or use of stolen credentials
Accounting event after authentication for user phopkins via /bin/su, indicating session tracking after credential use
Credential acquisition (setcred) event for phopkins via /bin/su, confirming possible credential manipulation
Session open event for phopkins via /bin/su, indicating session establishment for persistence or further actions
